metadata.value: Taspaco, Jeimar; Moran, Jose; Valero, Frenly. 2015. Convenio CVC CIAT. Story Map (Available from: http://arcg.is/1M2w5jB). Centro International de Agricultura Tropical (CIAT).

En el marco del convenio CVC-CIAT #033 “Aunar esfuerzos y recursos humanos, económicos y técnicos para realizar acciones en el marco de la adaptación y la mitigación al Cambio Climático en el Valle del Cauca” se ha consolidado un espacio multisectorial e interinstitucional llamado Red Interinstitucional de Cambio Climático.
El convenio busca la Institucionalización de la temática de Cambio Climático (CC) en la gestión ambiental y la planeación para el desarrollo. De esta forma se fortalecerá la capacidad regional para la gestión de proyectos relacionados con cambio climático y la incorporación de la temática en el ordenamiento ambiental del territorio.

item.name: Exploring dryland cereals and legumes for addressing food security: ATLAS DCL CGIAR, Research Program on Dryland Cereals and Legumes Agri-Food Systems

metadata.value: Castaño, Silvia-Elena; Hyman, Glenn; Rivera, Ovidio; Espinosa, Herlin. 2016. Exploring dryland cereals and legumes for addressing food security: ATLAS DCL CGIAR, Research Program on Dryland Cereals and Legumes Agri-Food Systems. Story Map (Available from: http://arcg.is/1TXBZEY0). International Center for Tropical Agriculture (CIAT).

Population growth and climate change threatens the world’s capacity to produce food into the future. Dryland cereal and legume (DCL) crops are part of any global solution to food security challenges. But these crops are often overlooked and under researched when compared to the main staples such as rice, wheat and maize. What are the priority regions for research on dryland cereals and legumes? This study determined the priority regions for research on these crops. The DCL crops are chickpea, common bean, cowpea, faba bean, groundnut, lentil, pigeon pea, soybean, barley, pearl millet, small millet and sorghum.
Exploring dryland cereals and legumes for addressing food security: ATLAS DCL CGIAR, Research Program on Dryland Cereals and Legumes Agri-Food Systems

item.name: Engaging Farmers and Experts in Feedback loops - the 5Q approach

metadata.value: CIAT. 2015. Engaging Farmers and Experts in Feedback loops - the 5Q approach. Story Map (Available from: http://csi.maps.arcgis.com/apps/MapSeries/index.html?appid=f221430bc7b64633b3d20fcc979f5637). International Center for Tropical Agriculture (CIAT).

An overview of CIAT’s pioneering new approach to increase the impact of research projects. 5Q is a simple, cheap and potentially highly-effective monitoring and evaluation system that has been tested in Tanzania.
Engaging Farmers and Experts in Feedback loops - the 5Q approach

metadata.value: CIAT. 2015. Traveling the world with crop wild relatives: dare to explore the amazing world. Story Map (Available from: http://arcg.is/1W7VajG). International Center for Tropical Agriculture (CIAT).

metadata.value: Quintero, Marcela; Castañeda-Álvarez, Nora P; Sachet, Erwan; Tello, Jhon Jairo; Valencia, Jefferson. 2015. Sustainable Amazonian Landscapes Project. Story Map (Available from: http://arcg.is/1PLVujh). International Center for Tropical Agriculture (CIAT).

Colombia and Peru host together 23% of the Amazon. Both countries are committed to reduce their greenhouse gases emissions, improve national and local capacities to adapt to climate change, enhance local livelihoods in forests and reduce net deforestation.
With the aim of contributing to these commitments, we selected two sites to be our areas of study in the Peruvian and Colombian Amazon: Yurimaguas (Peru) and Caquetá (Colombia), where we will conduct participatory research with national partners and local communities, and implement and assess the benefits of sustainable agricultural systems.

item.name: Lessons from Panama on combining REDD+ and land restoration to reduce net emissions

metadata.value: Rivera, Ovidio; Hyman, Glenn; Castaño, Silvia-Elena; Espinosa, Herlin; Labatte, Gabriel; Mariscal, Emilio; Montenegro, Ricardo. 2016. Lessons from Panama on combining REDD+ and land restoration to reduce net emissions. Story Map. (Available from: http://arcg.is/1PLXasO) International Center for Tropical Agriculture (CIAT) and UN-REDD Programme.

Panama, like other tropical countries, is undergoing land-use change that is contributing to greenhouse gas emissions. An analysis was made of the principal land-use changes, losses and gains of carbon stocks and potential impacts on livelihoods. We also analyzed the potential of policies to reduce net emissions through the REDD and Alliance for the Million Hectares (AMH).
Lessons from Panama on combining REDD+ and land restoration to reduce net emissions

item.name: Fiebre de Oro en el Amazonas Peruano

metadata.value: Menzinger, Bernadette; Paz, Paula Andrea; Bautista, Oscar. 2015. Fiebre de Oro en el Amazonas Peruano. Story Map (Available from: http://arcg.is/1MR1oQN). Centro Internacional de Agricultura Tropical (CIAT) y Terra-i.

El siguiente Storymaps relata en siete pestañas la problemática actual causada por la minería de oro en uno de los ecosistemas más afectados en la cuenca Amazónica de Perú, específicamente en la región de Madre de Dios.
Fiebre de Oro en el Amazonas Peruano

item.name: Bittersweet chocolate: the climate change impacts on cocoa production in Ghana

metadata.value: Bunn, Christian; Läderach, Peter; Quaye, Amos; Muilerman, Sander; Lundy, Mark. 2015. Bittersweet chocolate: the climate change impacts on cocoa production in Ghana. Story Map (Available from: http://arcg.is/1Sg047s). International Center for Tropical Agriculture (CIAT).
Climate change will be bittersweet for cocoa in Ghana. It will be less affected than other producer nations, but adaptation will be a tough challenge.
Bittersweet chocolate: the climate change impacts on cocoa production in Ghana
CLIMATE CHANGE, AGRICULTURE AND FOOD SECURITY

metadata.value: Smith, Georgina; Graziosi, Ignazio; Parker, Louis; Wyckhuys, Kris. 2015. Achilles' Heel: a story map. Story Map. (Available from http://arcg.is/25Kj7lX). International Center for Tropical Agriculture (CIAT).
A story about the vital importance of cassava in Southeast Asia, and the many risks this “Rambo root” faces from pest and disease outbreaks.
